discussion.content: B is correct; it uses the lowest AD out of all the routes presented that go to the 10.10.13.0/25 subnet. A is a default route and would only be used if there wasn't a route to that subnet in the routing table.

comments.content:
A is not listed in the routing table

Based on the default route entry configured on R1 from the exhibit, a default route would look like this:
0.0.0.0/0 [1/0] via 10.10.10.2

B is a valid entry + it has the lowest AD (given that all route entries have the same prefix length)

discussion.content:
Longest prefix match is preferred over any AD value. 
Here, although the default route uses AD of 1 ,it isn't the proper match for the destination. 
Destination address is 10.10.13.10 and the longest prefix match for that is 10.10.13.0/25.
There are currently 3 routes configured for that destination each with different AD value and also OSPF is running. 
Now when you first have the longest prefix match then only you check the AD value. So that would make the route with AD of 108 the perfect path for the destination.
Router make decision based on the following checklist in order.
1. Longest prefix match
2. AD 
3. Metric
This is just a high level overview but for the CCNA I think this will suffice.

comments.content: Default routes are only used when there's no route in the routing table that matches our destination.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The default route 0.0.0.0 via 10.10.10.2 is not chosen by R1 to reach Host B because specific routes take precedence over the default route. In routing decisions, routers always prefer the most specific match for a destination in the routing table. SO Routers always choose a route with the longest prefix length (the most specific match) over a less specific one.

A is the answer because it is a static route indicated by an administrative distance of 1, being the lowest of all routes to Host B (others being dynamically learnt via OSPF), it is chosen as the preferred route.

comments.content: R1 sees 10.10.10.10 directly since they are in the same network (10.10.10.8/30). Correct answer is B.

A default route is a route that takes effect when no other route is available for an IP destination address. In our case, we have a route that matches the destination and thus the default route won't be used.
The correct answer is B

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Since the network 10.10.10.8/30 is not advertised in the OSPF configuration and there is no specific route to 10.10.10.10 in the routing table, R1 wouldn't have a direct route to reach 10.10.10.10. In this scenario, R1 would typically follow the default behavior of selecting the best match in its routing table. The best match among the routes listed would be the default route
different routing protocol to the same destination will be selected by AD so the answer is B
Choice B coz it has lowest AD and it is the most specific one
Very tricky haha

Selected Answer: B
OSFP routing, indicated by area 0 routing command, has AD of 110. There is a floating static route configured with 108 AD. As the configured static route's AD is lower (108) than the OSPF's default AD (110) it will route the traffic via 10.10.10.10 because it has the lowest AD and thus will be put into the routing table.

Selected Answer: B
Because all routes point to the same subnet (10.10.13.0/25). So the route with the smallest AD value will be added to the routing table.
AD: OSPF (110), 10.10.10.10 (108), 10.10.10.6 (110), 10.10.10.2 (110)
Know your default routing protocol ADs!

B is correct!
Router prefers static route over dynamic route 
Router prefers Lowest AD
IT WILL USE THE DEFAULT / STATIC ROUTE 10.10.10.2 IT'S THE ONLY ONE ON THE DIAGRAM

comments.content:
As a reviewer for all of us, a router makes a forwarding decision by default using -
1st: longest prefix match (most specific)
2nd: AD
3rd: Routing protocol metric (hops/bandwidth/cost)
If the destination is not listed in the routing table (although we're only being shown the configurations, but we know the result), then the packets use the default gateway (quad zeroes). The thing is, it only gets picked if the destination is not on the routing table, but it is (at least that's what the global configurations is showing).
The default route will only be used If there's no entry in the routing table for a specific subnet. Hence, in this question 10.10.10.2 will not be used.

Selected Answer: C
Tested in the lab. The correct answer is C considering there is a typo. The command should be ipv6 address 2001:DB8:FFFF:FCF3::/64 eui-64. There must be a type on selection C.

Option ‘c’ is almost correct.

Option ‘a’ is incorrect. It assigns a static LLA to the interface (128 bits defined).
Option ‘b’ is incorrect. This assigns a static GUA to the interface (128 bits defined).
Option ‘c’ is incorrect. It is attempting to assign an IPv6 address, and add eui-64 to the end
Option ‘d’ is incorrect. There are no options to the command ipv6 address autoconfig.

However, imagine option ‘c’ had a typo; it is missing a ‘/’ before the 64.
Now, it would read: ipv6 address 2001:DB8:FFFF:FCF3::/64 eui-64

Then, option ‘c’ is correct.

Selected Answer: B

 the correct answer is letter "B" configuring the IP 2001:DB8:FFFF:FCF3::1/64 the router will provide a dynamic assignment via SLAAC as proposed in the statement. I did it in packet tracert and the hosts got IP automatically via SLAAC.
